<script id="s2n-api-setup" type="text/javascript">
function setupS2NApi(getS2NApiForPlayer) {
const s2nApi = getS2NApiForPlayer(document.querySelector('.s2nFriendlyFrame'));
if(document.querySelectorAll(".article-featured-media .media-wrapper").length){
	s2nApi.float = false;
}
};

<script>
	var OneSignal = window.OneSignal || [];
	OneSignal.push(["init", {
		appId: "45b13753-6440-4aca-963d-85dc2ea8679d",
		httpPermissionRequest: {
			enable: true
		},
		notifyButton: {
			enable: false /* Set to false to hide */
		},
		promptOptions: {
			customlink: {
				enabled: true, /* Required to use the Custom Link */
				style: "button", /* Has value of 'button' or 'link' */
				size: "medium", /* One of 'small', 'medium', or 'large' */
				color: {
					button: '#E12D30', /* Color of the button background if style = "button" */
					text: '#FFFFFF', /* Color of the prompt's text */
				},
				text: {
					subscribe: "Subscribe to push notifications", /* Prompt's text when not subscribed */
					unsubscribe: "Unsubscribe from push notifications", /* Prompt's text when subscribed */
					explanation: "Get updates from all sorts of things that matter to you", /* Optional text appearing before the prompt button */
				},
				unsubscribeEnabled: true, /* Controls whether the prompt is visible after subscription */
			}
		}
	}]);
</script>
<!-- End OneSignal initialization -->

<section class="article__header">
<a class="article__header__category | font-base text-400 weight-regular text-transform-upper color-light-gray" href="https://thehill.com/blogs/floor-action/senate/" title="Senate">Senate</a>
<div class="category__content__disclaimer | text-transform-upper text-300 color-hill-tv-red weight-semibold font-base">
</div>
<h1 class="page-title">
		Senate rejects Paulâs push to audit the Fed	</h1>
<section class="submitted-by | header__meta | text-transform-upper text-300 color-light-gray weight-semibold font-base desktop-only">
<span>
			by <a href="https://thehill.com/author/jordain-carney/">Jordain Carney</a> - 01/12/16 3:12 PM ET<br/>
</span>
<span>
<div class="social-share">
<a class="fb-share-button" data-desc="&lt;p&gt;Sens. </section>
<section class="submitted-by | header__meta | text-transform-upper text-300 color-light-gray weight-semibold font-base mobile-only">
			by <a href="https://thehill.com/author/jordain-carney/">Jordain Carney</a> - 01/12/16 3:12 PM ET<br/>
</section>
</section>
<!-- Social Share Links -->
</div>
<!-- Article Content -->
<div class="col-main | flow page-content overflow-hidden | font-base text-400">

<!-- Article Lead Media -->

<!-- Featured image -->

<img alt="" height="360" loading="eager" sizes="(max-width: 899px) 100vw, 640px" src="https://i0.wp.com/thehill.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2015/04/paulrand_090914gn.jpg?w=2000&amp;ssl=1" srcset="https://thehill.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2015/04/paulrand_090914gn.jpg?w=160&amp;h=90&amp;crop=1 160w, https://thehill.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2015/04/paulrand_090914gn.jpg?w=256&amp;h=144&amp;crop=1 256w, https://thehill.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2015/04/paulrand_090914gn.jpg?w=320&amp;h=180&amp;crop=1 320w, https://thehill.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2015/04/paulrand_090914gn.jpg?w=512&amp;h=288&amp;crop=1 512w, https://thehill.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2015/04/paulrand_090914gn.jpg?w=640&amp;h=360&amp;crop=1 640w, https://thehill.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2015/04/paulrand_090914gn.jpg?w=645&amp;h=363&amp;crop=1 876w, https://thehill.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2015/04/paulrand_090914gn.jpg?w=645&amp;h=363&amp;crop=1 960w, https://thehill.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2015/04/paulrand_090914gn.jpg?w=645&amp;h=363&amp;crop=1 1280w, https://thehill.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2015/04/paulrand_090914gn.jpg?w=645&amp;h=363&amp;crop=1 1752w, https://thehill.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2015/04/paulrand_090914gn.jpg?w=645&amp;h=363&amp;crop=1 1920w, https://thehill.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2015/04/paulrand_090914gn.jpg?w=645&amp;h=363&amp;crop=1 2560w" width="640"/>

<!-- Article Text -->
<div class="article__text | body-copy | flow">
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/loose.dtd">

<html><body><p>The Senate on Tuesday rejected Sen. Rand Paulâs (R-Ky.) controversial proposal to audit the Federal Reserve, turning aside a bill that has drawn the ire of the business community and the White House.Â </p>
<p>The Senate voted 53-44 on taking up the presidential hopefulâs measure. Sixty votes were needed to move forward.</p>
<p>{mosads}Paul won some bipartisan support for the legislation, with Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.), another presidential candidate, voting in favor. Democratic Sen. Tammy Baldwin (Wis.) backed the bill as well.</p>
<p>Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.), who is also running for president, supported moving forward with Paulâs legislation, while White House rival Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas) missed the vote. Sen. Bob Corker (Tenn.) was the only Republican to vote against the bill.Â </p>
<p>Paul had pressured Sanders and Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) to back his proposal, portraying it as a test of their commitment to taking on Wall Street.</p>
<p>âWeâve had a lot of Democrats who claim that theyâre concerned about big banks and big banks controlling things and a revolving door between Wall Street and big banks and the Federal Reserve,â Paul told reporters during a conference call Monday. âWeâll see if any of those loud voices â Bernie Sanders, Elizabeth Warren â are they loud voices that really are for more oversight of the banking system?âÂ </p>
<p>Warren voted against the bill.Â </p>
<p>Sanders, who in the past worked with Paulâs father, former Rep. Ron Paul (R-Texas), on similar âAudit the Fedâ legislation, said the new bill would help build on his 2010 push to require an audit of the central bankâs emergency lending.</p>
<p>âRequiring the Government Accountability Office to conduct a full and independent audit of the Fed each and every year, would be an important step towards making the Federal Reserve a more democratic institution that is responsive to the needs of ordinary Americans rather than the billionaires on Wall Street,â the Independent senator said in a statement.Â </p>
<p>Paulâs legislation, which would increase congressional oversight of the Fed and require it to undergo an audit by the Government Accountability Office, faced an uphill battle. Ahead of the vote, only 26 Republicans had signed on as co-sponsors.</p>
<p>Sen. Dick Durbin (D-Ill.) told The Hill while he expected the vote would be close, âat this point I think itâs going to be difficult for the Republicans to get 60 votes.â</p>
<p>Democrats suggested that Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.), who supported the bill, was wasting floor time by making Paulâs legislation the first bill of 2016. McConnell backs Paulâs presidential run.</p>
<p>Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) dismissed Paulâs proposal as a âsham.â</p>
<p>âRepublicans have been trying to undermine the Federal Reserve mandate to strive toward full employment,â he <a href="https://twitter.com/SenatorReid/status/686931911936225280" rel="noopener" target="_blank">added</a> on Tuesday morning.</p>
<p>Sen. Sherrod Brown (D-Ohio), the ranking member of the Banking Committee, added ahead of the vote that the legislation âreally solves nothing but to politicize the Fed.âÂ </p>
<p>For Paul, the vote in the Senate was a chance to grab the spotlight ahead of a weekend trip to New Hampshire, the second contest in the Republican primary.</p>
<p>After a promising start, he has struggled to break out in the field and is now coming in near the bottom of the polls.Â </p>
<p>Fox Business Network announced that the Kentucky Republican didnât qualify for the main-stage debate on Thursday night, and Paul has refused to participate in the earlier undercard bout.</p>
<p>Republicans broadly argue that recent policy decisions by the Federal Reserve â including its handling of the 2008 financial crisis â underscore the need for more oversight of the powerful central bank.</p>
<p>Sen. Pat Toomey (R-Pa.), who is up for reelection in November, said that while he had been skeptical of Paulâs legislation, âthe dangerous behavior that the Fed has engaged in for years now means they have squandered the right to be independent.â</p>
<p>Sen. Richard Shelby (R-Ala.), the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, had previously voiced opposition to Paulâs proposal, but voted Tuesday to move forward with it.</p>
<p>âI think we ought to debate it,â he told reporters on Monday evening. âIâm interested in oversight and that might be what heâs interested in.â</p>
<p>Federal Reserve officials have fought fiercely against Paulâs legislation, suggesting that it would allow Congress to weigh in on financial policy âin real time.â</p>
<p>Fed Chairwoman Janet Yellen sent a letter to Senate leadership late last week saying that she opposes the bill and warning, if signed into law, it could damage the economy.</p>
<p>The White House last year called Paulâs proposal âdangerous.â</p>
<p>âWhat that bill is about is about Congress supplanting its judgment as to what monetary policy should be,â said Jason Furman, chairman of Obamaâs Council of Economic Advisers. âCongress shouldnât be telling the Fed what to do with monetary policy.â</p>
<p>Business groups had also expressed strong opposition to the bill.</p>
<p>The U.S. Chamber of Commerce, the most powerful industry lobby in Washington, issued an open letter urging senators to vote against the legislation, calling it âunnecessary.â</p>
<p>âCreating outside pressures that could politicize monetary policy decisions would likely harm the market foundations needed to fuel the free enterprise system,â wrote Bruce Josten, the Chamberâs executive vice president of government affairs.</p>
<p>Tuesdaysâ vote was the first time Paulâs legislation was allowed to come up.Â </p>
<p>Conservative groups rallied behind the measure, with FreedomWorks legislative affairs manager Josh Withrow saying late last week that if central banks âhave nothing to hide from the American people, they shouldnât fear transparency.â</p>
<p><em>This story was updated at 7:45 p.m.</em></p>
</body></html>
</div>

		Rand Paul		</a>
<a class="tags__item color-light-gray weight-semibold" href="
		https://thehill.com/people/sherrod-brown/		">
		Sherrod Brown		</a>
<a class="tags__item color-light-gray weight-semibold" href="
		https://thehill.com/people/tammy-baldwin/		">
		Tammy Baldwin		</a>
<a class="tags__item color-light-gray weight-semibold" href="
		https://thehill.com/people/ted-cruz/		">
		Ted Cruz		</a>
</section>
<!-- Article Footer Copyright -->

<div class="featured-cards__medium__content">
<h1 class="featured-cards__medium__headline | weight-semibold | pad-bottom-500 | leading-flat">
<a data-link-label="Rising: March 7, 2023" data-link-pinned="false" data-link-position="2" data-link-type="content-link" href="https://thehill.com/hilltv/rising/3887831-rising-march-7-2023/">
			Rising: March 7, 2023			</a>
</h1>
<div class="medium-byline__author">
<!-- Other featured cards byline -->
<div class="featured-cards__byline | text-300 | weight-semibold |">
<!-- desktop template -->
<div class="desktop-only">
<!-- Author is used for: Medium Ft Card, Large Ft Card -->
<span class="featured-cards__byline__author | color-light-gray | text-transform-upper">
				by TheHill.com			</span>
<!-- Byline Date: Date format is different for each Ft Card  -->
<span class="featured-cards__byline__date | color-light-gray">
			03/07/23 11:50 AM ET		</span>
</div>
